Name: Sumatra Mandheling Washed
Review: ong>Admirers of the traditional Sumatra profile will find very little of it here, but they will find a quietly complex and gently balanced cup.
Coffee Origin: Lake Toba or Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Volkopi Peaberry
Review: ong>An attractive balance of drying, slightly savory pungency and chocolaty sweetness in this original variation on the Sumatra cup.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Wahana Natural Sumatra
Review: ong>Complex, engaging variation on the dried-in-the-fruit cup; crisp yet lush, original.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Toba Batak PB
Review: ong>Moderately dark-roasted and delicately original variation on the Sumatra wet-hulled cup.
Coffee Origin: Lake Toba growing region, northern Sumatra.

Name: Sumatra Lintong-Opung BR
Review: ong>The pungent, berry-toned dark chocolate showed an almost Kenya-like intensity in this complexly original variation on the Sumatra cup.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Bodhi Batak PB
Review: ong>The earthy side of elegance in a fine and rather traditional variation on the great wet-hulled Sumatra profile.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Lake Tawar Sc 19+
Review: ong>This well-structured variant on the Sumatra profile, with its pungent fruit and big, juicy acidity, should please aficionados of the type.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Golden Mandheling
Review: ong>The Sumatra wet-hulled profile takes on a sweet yet zesty, peppery character in this fine lighter-roasted variation on the style.
Coffee Origin: Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Wahana Natural
Review: ong>An elegant and engaging variation on the dried-in-the-fruit cup, with the fermenty edge to the fruit lush yet crisply restrained.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Tano Batak
Review: ong>Spice and butterscotch suggestions in particular distinguish this fine, elegant variation on the great Sumatra wet-hulled cup.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Tano Batak Sumatra
Review: ong>Those likely to enjoy a fine variation on the classic Sumatra structure: simultaneously tart, juicy and richly earthy.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Lintong Sumatra Dolok Sangul
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the classic Sumatra balance between lush fruit and deeper, pungent notes, in this case the moist, spicy earthiness of fresh pipe tobacco.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Momma Bear Espresso
Review: ong>Great natural sweetness makes this espresso a fine choice for those with a grown-up sweet tooth, but any espresso enthusiast should enjoy its massive but balanced complexity.
Coffee Origin: Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala; Sidamo growing region, Ethiopia.

Name: Espresso Motoretta
Review: ong>This versatile single-origin blend is classically balanced as a straight shot and gently complex in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Single Origin Chiang Rai Doi Chang
Review: ong>Those who prefer their dark-roasted coffees sweet-toned and gentle.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere G1
Review: ong>Splendid example of the extravagantly aromatic Yirgacheffe cup. Will please and excite any way you take it, but should make a particularly fine iced coffee.

Name: Nyeri Peaberry of Kenya
Review: ong>Sweetly dry, berry-toned Kenya elegance in a moderately dark-roasted format.

Name: Arnulfo Leguizamo Colombia
Review: ong>Those who prefer a rich, deeply complex cup with a profound natural sweetness.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Indonesia Organic Java
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in an unusual origin (Java village garden coffees) with a quietly but distinctly unusual aromatic, chocolate- and halvah-like.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gatomboya AA
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the intense, sweetly bright style of the great Kenya cup.

Name: Maragogype Honey Process
Review: ong>Maragogipe is generally known for its big, showy beans rather than for its cup character, but this Maragogipe defies expectation with a lush and original aromatic profile.

Name: Papua New Guinea Barolda Estate
Review: ong>Those who prefer brisk, elegant delicacy in a morning cup.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Ayinage Reserve
Review: ong>A moderately dark roast develops the rich complexity of the floral notes in this fine rendition of the great Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu Rio Jorca
Review: ong>Subtle and quietly original. Definitely don’t ruin the delicacy of this gently engaging coffee with whitener.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica

Name: Ecuador Lucas Vera
Review: ong>Those who admire well-structured, balanced profiles in the classic Latin-American mode.

Name: Ulos Batak Sumatra Peaberry
Review: ong>Almost syrupy sweet, juicily tart, with profound and original complexity. An amazing Sumatra.

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu
Review: ong>Classic Costa Rica balance with original, intriguing aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Tarrazu growing region, central Costa Rica.

Name: Papua New Guinea Boroida Estate
Review: ong>An unusual coffee, simultaneously sweet and floral with a crisp, underlying cocoaish aromatic wood note that gives the profile authority.

Name: Fair Trade Organic Mexico Chiapas
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a rich but delicate cup with quietly original aromatics and excellent social and environmental credentials.

Name: Jacob’s Estate Taiwan
Review: ong>North Americans interested in an unusual origin, and Taiwanese interested in a home-grown espresso with a pleasingly quiet, chocolaty presence.

Name: Mexican El Triunfo Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a fine example of a round, deep, less acidy profile.

Name: Peruvian Cafe Feminino Cacanor Coop
Review: ong>A balanced, delicate espresso with good presence in milk and comprehensive feel-good credentials.

Name: Panama Boquete Finca Kotowa Don-K Natural
Review: ong>Those espresso drinkers who, like Ken, value the aromatic wood, deep fruit and caramelly sweetness of good American whiskey.

Name: AIPEP Bolivian Fair Trade Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy softness and balance in a medium-roasted espresso.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Guatemala Finca La Perla
Review: ong>What we think of as the Guatemala character, with its balanced brightness complicated by chocolate and spice notes, is well represented in this espresso.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: El Salvador Natural Finca Malacara
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big, fruity and oaky red wines.
Coffee Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana regioin, El Salvador.

Name: Costa Rica Lomas Al Rio Honey Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy citrusy but balanced straight shots, with a rounding complexity. Maintains character nicely in cappuccino-volumes of milk.
Coffee Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Ninety Plus Nekisse N2 S.O. Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a relatively brisk and clean version of the often lush brandy and fruit of dried-in-the-fruit “naturals.”
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Guji Natural
Review: ong>This relatively chastely balanced dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia gives us both wine and fruit nuance while preserving some Ethiopia floral notes. Superb in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Guatemala Santa Sofia Lot 3
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a brightly fruit-toned but chocolaty straight shot with full, syrupy mouthfeel. Retains character well in cappuccino-sized milk.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Grade 1 Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy brightly aromatic, zesty, silkily light-bodied straight shots and sweetly citrusy cappuccini.

Name: Organic Colombia SOS Fondo Paez Cooperative
Review: ong>Classic coffee, classically roasted for espresso to develop both depth and sweetness and a wide range of aromatic nuance.
Coffee Origin: Valle de Cauca Department, western Colombia

Name: Kenya AB Top Lot Single-Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Powerful yet elegantly balanced straight-shot espresso.

Name: Ethiopia Dry Process Saris Abaya
Review: ong>Expresses the sweet, brandy-like character of Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffees with discretion and elegance, allowing equal billing to the heady floral and fruit notes inherent in native Ethiopia coffee varieties.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ninety Plus Kemgin W2 Ethiopia
Review: ong>Classic in structure and exotic in aroma and flavor, both as straight shot and in cappuccino-volumes of milk.

Name: Guatemala Finca La Esperanza Pacamara COE 7
Review: ong>Those who buy this coffee for the novelty of the very large bean size will be further rewarded by a quietly original aroma/flavor complex: the butter and nut suggestions are complicated by juicy citrus and lush flowers.

Name: Pedregal de Cauca Colombia
Review: ong>Classic in structure yet subtly surprising and original in its aromatics, this coffee should please classicists and explorers alike.

Name: Kiawamururu Kenya A/B
Review: ong>Bright, balanced, refreshing morning cup.

Name: Black Bar Espresso 2
Review: ong>Balanced structure and intriguing aroma/flavor in a distinctive straight-shot espresso.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Sidamo
Review: ong>A classically intense floral-and-citrus washed Ethiopia coffee that will please lovers of the type and perhaps attract some converts as well.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: El Salvador El Nazareno
Review: ong>Those who enjoy subtly unusual aromatics and silky balance.
Coffee Origin: Apaneca Municipality, Ahuachapan Department, El Salvador.

Name: Neo Mocha-Java
Review: ong>Deep, richly forceful espresso both in milk and as a straight shot.

Name: Black Bar Espresso 1
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a rounded, citrusy brightness and impressive, delicately creamy mouthfeel in an elegant straight shot.

Name: Honduras El Praiso
Review: ong>Those who prefer a deep, round, resonantly pungent cup with considerable complexity and backgrounded but vibrant acidity.

Name: Cafe Est Espresso
Review: ong>Those who prefer a robust, richly bittersweet straight shot and an assertive presence in milk.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gatomboya
Review: ong>A very ripe, elegant acidity leads in this quietly classic Kenya.

Name: Taiwan Musk Coffee
Review: ong>Those in pursuit of the exotic and experimental. Displays some of the orangy nut character of authentic civet-cat coffees. In other respects, a cleanly balanced coffee from an unusual origin.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe ECX
Review: ong>Yirgacheffe is already one of the world’s most explosively complex coffees; this is a Yirgacheffe on steroids, huge and astounding in its aromatic impact.

Name: Ethiopia Dry Process Grade 1 Aricha Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Superb coffee, balanced yet alive with aromatic intrigue.

Name: Geisha P.E.B. (RFA)
Review: ong>An opportunity to sample one of the coffee’s most singular experiences, the crisp, lush intensity of the great Geisha profile.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling Wahana
Review: ong>An exceptional and unusual dried-in-the-fruit coffee, with the sweetness and aromatic complexity characteristic of the type expressed cleanly without the distraction of over-the-top fruit. Not your typical Sumatra, by the way; closer in character to certain of the finest dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopias.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Geisha S94
Review: ong>Intricate and luscious; richly sweet. Caramel, hibiscus and rose, candied-ginger, and honeydew melon in aroma and small-cup. Very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet floral notes and buttery richness carries through a remarkable finish. Richly flavor saturated in two- to four-parts milk with a touch of grapefruit acidity, all of which is buoyantly juxtapositioned with the milky sweetness.

Name: Tanzania Ruvuma
Review: ong>A balanced, comfortable coffee with a plush mouthfeel and flavor notes ranging from pungently crisp to lushly sweet.

Name: Bolivia Copacabana
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth, resonance and a juicy rather than bright acidity.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Ecuador Vilcabamba
Review: ong>Those who prefer quietly resonant, gently complex coffees.

Name: TCA House Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy complex, discreetly exotic espresso blends.
Coffee Origin: Cauca Department, Colombia; Illubabor, Ethiopia; Santa Ana region, El Salvador.

Name: Malawi Zomba Mountain
Review: ong>Those who enjoy crisp, slightly earthy and savory beverages.

Name: Costa Rica Don Jose Micro Lot
Review: ong>A quiet, comfortable coffee in the best sense; lively yet balanced, gentle yet engaging.
Coffee Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Signature Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig-owners who prefer a very mild, very quietly nuanced medium-roasted cup. This particular sample seemed a bit faded. It is possible that other samples of the same product may be livelier.

Name: Caribou Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A mild but crisp, chocolate-walnut-toned cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Colombian Fair Trade Select (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig-owners who value a sweetly crisp, balanced breakfast cup with Fair-Trade credentials.

Name: Gourmet Selections Colombian Decaf (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A pleasant darker-roasted decaf for Keurig owners, sweetly roasty with some hints of savory depth.

Name: Sumatra Dark (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Offers in a K-cup format some of the earthy robustness that fans of dark-roasted traditional Sumatra coffees admire.

Name: Mahogany Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Classically rich and crisply chocolate-toned dark roast for Keurig owners.

Name: Monk-Shot Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>A quietly balanced, gently nuanced breakfast cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Tribute Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A satisfying dark-roasted cup for Keurig-owners. The K-cup format seems to mute the usual bitterness of the dark roast, allowing a quiet but pleasing aromatic complexity to move forward.
Coffee Origin: Ethiopia; Sumatra; Papua New Guinea; Colombia.

Name: Newman’s Own Organics Special Decaf (K-Cup)
Review: ong>An almost miraculously good decaffeinated coffee for Keurig owners; the gently lively acidity, smooth mouthfeel and quietly complex flavor are particularly impressive. No raw nut or woody decaf notes that we could detect, with the only (almost hypothetical) decaffeination-related flaw a slight fading in aroma and finish.

Name: Original Donut Shop (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A lively, engagingly complex breakfast cup with a hint of the elegant dry berry character usually found in only the most distinguished of coffee origins.

Name: Sumatran Reserve Extra Bold (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Impressively authentic version of the classic darker roasted, robust Sumatra cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Kenya AA (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Unusual opportunity for Keurig owners to enjoy a distinctive version of one of the world’s great single-origin coffees.

Name: Tchembe Single Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy smoothly bright, citrus- and floral-toned straight shots and short milk drinks.

Name: Twisted 2.0 Espresso
Review: ong>A complete and satisfying straight shot, syrupy and complex. Tends to dominate in short milk, but sweetens and rounds in taller milk.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
Review: ong>Quietly original in its graceful integration of savory depth and floral sweetness.

Name: Papua New Guinea Koban AA
Review: ong>Finely balanced, classically complete cup should satisfy almost any coffee drinker.
Coffee Origin: Jiwaka Province, western highlands of Papua New Guinea.

Name: Bali Kintamani Highlands
Review: ong>Those who enjoy variations on the gently fermented, natural or dried-in-the-fruit cup. This version is drier and more rye-whisky-toned than most, which tend to be sweeter and more brandy-like.

Name: Peru Cajamarca Cenfrocafe
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a briskly savory-edged breakfast cup.

Name: Mexico Ixhuatlan Finca La Playa
Review: ong>Classic Mexico: clean, softly bright, quietly complex, with a hint of the elegant dry berry note associated with the heirloom Bourbon variety.

Name: Bolivia Illiimani
Review: ong>A classic Bolivia cup: lovely structure with gentle but vibrant acidity; quietly complex aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Canton Illimani, Caranavi Province, west-central Bolivia.

Name: Bolivia Buenavista Colonia Villa Rosario
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth and savory complexity in a brewed coffee.

Name: Decaf Organic Papua New Guinea
Review: ong>An unusual opportunity for decaf drinkers to enjoy the sweetly tart, grapefruity character of a fine Papua New Guinea coffee offered as a single-origin.

Name: Chickadee Medium Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a balanced, chocolate-toned darker roasted cup.

Name: Peru Organic Puno
Review: ong>Those who enjoy purity and delicacy in a crisply refreshing morning cup.

Name: Ethiopia Ninety Plus Kemgin
Review: ong>This striking but accessible coffee should please anyone, while aficionados of the great Ethiopia wet-processed profile will find its wide range of aromatics familiar yet arrestingly original.
Coffee Origin: Nekempte District, Oromia Region, western Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Riakiberu Peaberry
Review: ong>Quintessential Kenya, alive with characteristic Kenya berry notes lushly sweet yet crisply dry and animated by a ripe and accessible acidity.

Name: Rwanda Nyamasheke
Review: ong>Offers everything: Seething, opulent flavor atop a firm, classic structure.

Name: El Salvador Santa Marta Honey
Review: ong>Those who value sweetness without sentimentality.

Name: Bolivia Carmelo Yujra Organic
Review: ong>A complete and classic Latin-American-style cup, with big body, bright but balanced acidity, and a lush and juicy set of flavor and aroma notes.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Papua New Guinea AA Akora
Review: ong>Anyone who enjoys purity without simplicity. Lively, balanced and classic.
Coffee Origin: Eastern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea

Name: Hawaii Kona Isla Prime Select
Review: ong>Nicely expresses the characteristic soft acidity, sweetness and delicate complexity of the finest Kona coffees.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Premium Roasted Thai Coffee Beans
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a pungently dark-roasted cup that preserves some sweetness and aromatic nuance.

Name: Bolivia Organic Buenavista 1738
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quietly balanced, crisp-finishing chocolate- and floral-toned cup.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Bolivia Caarnavi Buenavista Organic Light Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a lighter roasted, delicately brisk, cleanly honey-toned cup.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Peru Cenfrocafe Microlot
Review: ong>In many respects a classic Peru: soft, buoyant, balanced.

Name: Bolivia Organic Uchumachi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy delicacy and comfort in a genial medium-roasted cup.
Coffee Origin: Carnavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Ecuador Lucas Vera Typica
Review: ong>Those who enjoy naturally crisp, pleasingly bittersweet sensations. This definitely is not the bittersweetness of darker roasted coffees, for example, but is a very graceful bittersweet tartness reminiscent of certain fruits and berries.

Name: Bolivia Senda Salvaje Juan Yujra
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicately crisp citrus enveloped in honey, floral and cocoa-toned sweetness.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Peru Raul Mamani
Review: ong>Those who enjoy pungently sweet, complex beverages with a wide range of sensation, from citrusy tart to floral-toned sweet.

Name: Bolivia Organic Buenavista
Review: ong>Those who enjoy beverages that combine savory depth with complex sweetness.
Coffee Origin: Carnavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Organic Peru Huabal
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classically structured morning cup: bright, big-bodied, but balanced.

Name: Ecuador El Batan Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a very pure, balanced lighter-roasted cup, graceful and lyric.

Name: 100 Percent Puna Kazumura Reserve Peaberry Medium Dark
Review: ong>This would be a striking and unusual coffee from anywhere in the world, but it is a particular surprise coming from Hawaii, where sweetness and balance are the positive norm rather than the startling aromatic originality of this Puna peaberry.

Name: Colombia Granja La Esperanza Geisha
Review: ong>A crisp, roast-influenced version of the great Gesha profile, with its lush flowers and brisk chocolate.

Name: Heart of Bold
Review: ong>An ultra-dark roast for acidity-avoiders that retains some sweetness and chocolate despite the rigor of the roast.

Name: Stuck in the Middle
Review: ong>Acidity avoiders who enjoy a crisply roasty but gently complex cup.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto Pandora Del Carmen Pacamara
Review: ong>The particular sensory genius of the Pacamara variety is exhibited well here: savory-sweet depth, crisp cedary chocolate, floral top notes and a slightly bitterish, brightly zesty citrus. The classic crossed with the exotic.

Name: Costa Rica Coffea Diversa Farm
Review: ong>Those who enjoy purity, elegance and delicate complexity in a lighter-roasted cup.

Name: Emilse Luna Colombian Huila
Review: ong>Tart and savory tendencies balance great sweetness in a structure that supports an intriguingly complex set of aromas and flavors.

Name: Colombia Villa Loyola Caturra
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a coffee that is easy-drinking and accessible yet still offers aromatic intrigue.

Name: El Salvador Malacara B Farm
Review: ong>Those who enjoy complex expressions of richly and sweetly tart sensations in juices and cuisine.
Coffee Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana regioin, El Salvador.

Name: Belekatu Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A fine exemplar of the great Yirgacheffe cup, juicy, bright and dramatically aromatic.

Name: Rutana Burundi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy Central African tart berry and floral chocolate character in a briskly bright but balanced cup.

Name: Ethiopia Saris Abaya
Review: ong>A massive, robust example of the fruity, brandyish style of Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit coffee, with a savory weight in cup and finish complicating the usual big, blueberryish sweetness. Those coffee drinkers who know and value Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit coffee should enjoy this hearty variant.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Our Best Decaf
Review: ong>Decaf drinkers who value a bright but richly syrupy espresso with solid presence in milk.

Name: Organic Colombia Fondo Paez Cooperative
Review: ong>Those who prefer a crisp but deep-toned and caramelly breakfast cup.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy rich, chocolaty darker roasted espresso blends. Holds up well in taller milk drinks.

Name: Bajawa Flores Indonesia
Review: ong>Lovers of the more refined style of Sumatras may find this coffee interesting and appealing, as will those who enjoy beverages that combine great natural sweetness with a crisp, dry mouthfeel.

Name: La Esmeralda Mario Carnaval 2012 Panama
Review: ong>The rare and marvelous Gesha at its most characteristic: startlingly distinctive flavor and a complete and flawless structure.

Name: Rutana Burundi Espresso
Review: ong>A superb single-origin espresso, which illustrates how successfully the pleasures of a sweetly bright, high-grown coffee can be deepened but not muted for espresso brewing.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Gaturiri Peaberry
Review: ong>In particular, those who enjoy the grand style of Kenya, big, juicy, bright, crisp, but anyone who wants a fine breakfast cup as arresting as it is balanced.

Name: Yukro Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who value intensity and excitement in flavor and sweet-toned, juicy acidity.
Coffee Origin: Gera District of Oromia Region, western Ethiopia.

Name: Colombia Huila Los Naranjos
Review: ong>Those who value pure, delicately classic breakfast coffees. Don’t even think about putting whitener in this one.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southwestern Colombia.

Name: Ethiopia Dry Process Aricha
Review: ong>Nice balance of lush, slightly fermenty fruit and floral sweetness with a gently drying briskness should please those who enjoy such juxtapositions in ales and whiskies, for example, or good port wines.

Name: Gitega Burundi Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a deeply and richly tart straight shot or an authoritative coffee component in taller milk drinks.

Name: Tzampetey Guatemala
Review: ong>Those who prefer a round, quietly complex cup, comfortable with a hint of the exotic.

Name: Nicaragua Adeprofoca Maragogype
Review: ong>Usually the rare Maragogipe wows us with its giant beans but disappoints in the cup. This lot, however, displays an interesting and impressive sensory profile, making it an appealing buy both for the coffee curious and those simply interested in a satisfying and unusual cup.

Name: Rwanda
Review: ong>The style of coffee we used to call “after-dinner,” though its resonant richness, quiet complexity and roast-moderated acidity should please any time of day.

Name: Harfusa Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Smoothly tart and lushly sweet, surprisingly full in mouthfeel, deeply nuanced in aroma and flavor, this is a morning cup that both expresses and transcends classic.

Name: Sumatra Wahana Natural
Review: ong>A light but fully developed roast encourages expression of a massive and ultimately harmonious complexity that should surprise and please any coffee drinker save the most conventional in taste.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Colombia Tolima Planadas Lot 3
Review: ong>Lovers of very pure, delicately balanced beverages.

Name: Guatemalan Antigua Serena
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a crisply sweet, suavely nuanced breakfast cup.

Name: Stella Espresso
Review: ong>The tart raspberry-like fruit is attractive in the straight shot and particularly impressive in short milk.

Name: Kenya Kichwa Tembo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic, straightforward breakfast cup, sweetly bright but not sharp.

Name: Cosecha de Oro Colombia Light Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy gentle medium-roasted blends with soft acidity and quiet, layered flavor and aromatics.

Name: Traveler’s Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a roast-dominated but complex and chocolaty cup.

Name: Decaf Colombia Mountain Wash
Review: ong>Decaf drinkers will find some pleasures here, including smooth, pleasing mouthfeel and a nut-toned, caramelly sweetness.

Name: P.r.o. Gourmet
Review: ong>Versatile espresso; crisply chocolaty both as straight shot and in short milk.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: P.r.o. Selected
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a brisk, complex straight shot.

Name: Caffe Chat
Review: ong>Tart but smooth straight shot blooms nicely in short milk.
Coffee Origin: Antigua growing region, Guatemala; Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Bluekoff Single Origin Thai Espresso Blend (A4+A5)
Review: ong>Impressive straight-shot espresso, with buttery body and sweet depth, but perhaps at its best in short milk, where it retains its richness and individuality.

Name: Doi Chaang Wild Civet Passed Coffee
Review: ong>The provocative processing method via a mammal’s digestive tract produces a quietly notable coffee here, though more remarkable for classic balance than exotic strangeness. The combination of tart lemon and raisiny chocolate is a bit unusual in the sensory world of coffee, however, and here quite attractive.

Name: Mihuti Kenya Espresso
Review: ong>An engagingly aromatic and complex straight shot that develops with balance and rich nuance in cappuccino-sized milk.

Name: Kenya Igutha
Review: ong>The cushiony, plush acidity and floral sweetness makes this an accessible and inviting version of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Kenya Mukurweini Kamuchuni AA
Review: ong>Classic Kenya richly displays all the pleasures of the type: big but rounded acidity; elegantly complex, sweetly tart berry notes; silky mouthfeel.

Name: Kenya Kagumoini Mugaga Cooperative
Review: ong>Anyone who enjoys a briskly sweet morning cup; the particularly complex floral notes range from bitter and hoppy to lushly honeyish.
Coffee Origin: Karatina district, Nyeri growing region, Kenya.

Name: Alamid Coffee (Kopi Luwak)
Review: ong>One of the best luwaked coffees we have sampled over the past few years, with genuinely unique aromatics. Only you can decide whether those unique aromatics are worth the high price.

Name: Roar of Kenya
Review: ong>Those who enjoy distinctive single-origin profiles that have been rounded and deepened but not tamed for use in espresso applications. Maintains individuality even in short milk.

Name: Brazil Pocos de Caldas S.O. Espresso
Review: ong>Impressive complexity and depth of sensation in a single-origin espresso.

Name: EBENICA INTENSIVO 100 Percent Arabica
Review: ong>Deep and quietly complex, particularly as a straight shot.

Name: EBENICA HARMONELLE 100 Percent Arabica
Review: ong>The crisp floral notes are an engaging intrigue in this balanced, smooth espresso.

Name: EBENICA PIANO 100 Percent Arabica
Review: ong>Crisply sweet, balanced, both as straight shot and in short milk.

Name: Coffea Espresso Guatemala Los Olivos
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a roundly bright straight shot with very smooth mouthfeel. Dry and refreshingly brisk in short milk.
Coffee Origin: Hoja Blanca growing region, Huehuetenango Department, Guatemala.

Name: Ninety Plus Sillvia SK L95
Review: ong>Superb range of aromatics and flavor should please anyone who can afford this very rare coffee.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara Beneficio San Vicente Caracalillo
Review: ong>Tart, dry berry juxtaposed with floral sweetness makes this an attractive variation for those who enjoy the great SL28 Kenya profiles.

Name: Washed Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Those who value gentle excitement in a breakfast cup.

Name: Sweet Breeze
Review: ong>Those who value both depth and excitement in a versatile cup that should please in almost any time of the day or context, with or without whitener.
Coffee Origin: Kenya; Yirgacheffe region of Ethiopia; other undisclosed origins.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara Finca Las Brisas
Review: ong>A quietly complex, classically balanced breakfast cup.

Name: Simple Display
Review: ong>Those who prefer depth and resonance to brightness and excitement.

Name: Costa Rica Microlot Hortensia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy sweetness without sentimentality.

Name: La Bendicion Guatemala
Review: ong>Those who value skillfully light-roasted coffees of great purity that preserve a meadow-like freshness and brisk sweetness.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Wote Konga
Review: ong>A very pure, crisp, light-roasted example of the normally more lushly fruit-and-brandy-toned dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia profile. Think honeyish flowers and citrus rather than dark chocolate and blueberries.

Name: Guatemala Finca El Socorro Palo Blanco
Review: ong>The soft, exotic complexity of a fine Guatemala on steroids – powerful yet still subtle.

Name: Honduras El Cielito S.O. Espresso
Review: ong>Does well as a briskly aromatic straight shot and as an authoritative, chocolaty presence in longer milk drinks.

Name: Honduras Bertilio Reyes Portillo
Review: ong>Those who prefer the deep and vibrant to the bright and showy.

Name: El Salvador Finca Malacara B
Review: ong>Those who prefer quiet depth to bright display.
Coffee Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana regioin, El Salvador.

Name: Haitian
Review: ong>Unusual opportunity to taste a good Haitian coffee, with the chocolate and soft, rounded acidity long associated with this perennially troubled origin.

Name: Guatemala Trapichitos
Review: ong>Quietly exotic flavor and balanced structure in a light-roast presentation provides a satisfying variation on the Central America cup.
Coffee Origin: El Quiche Department, south central Guatemala

Name: Kenya Kiawamururu
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a brightly acidy yet sweetly nuanced cup.

Name: Ethiopia Gelana Abaya
Review: ong>Those who already know they enjoy the slightly fermented, fruit-toned Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit profile will enjoy this clean, elegant rendition of the type. For those who have never experimented with the style, an excellent starting point.
Coffee Origin: Kersa district, Oromia region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Ecuador La Bendicion de Dios & El Nogel
Review: ong>Superbly refined Latin American style breakfast cup should please any drinker of light- to medium-roasted coffees. The sweetly tart citrus and crisp cocoa give just enough grounding authority to the soft, enveloping floral character.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Karogoto
Review: ong>Lovers of dry but gently fragrant white table wines.

Name: Kenya Microlot AA Kamuchuni
Review: ong>Those who enjoy beverages that combine great sweetness with dry authority; certain floral but minerally white wines for example.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Pak Joner
Review: ong>Lovers of the great traditional Sumatra profile should enjoy this lively, elegantly complex version of the style.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Yirgacheffe Blue Nile
Review: ong>Superb, balanced but intensely aromatic example of the great Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Mexico Santa Teresa BCS 02: Cabernet Franc Barrel
Review: ong>Should make a superb dessert coffee, while aficionados of high-end coffee innovation will find it interesting, perhaps remarkable.

Name: Yirgacheffe Belekatu
Review: ong>Distinctive aromatics and an essential balance and sweetness should make this an attractive, exciting breakfast cup for almost any one.

Name: Gaturiri Nyeri Kenya
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the richly bright, juicy side of the great Kenya cup.
Coffee Origin: Nyeri growing region, Central Highlands, Kenya.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere
Review: ong>Fine version of the great Yirgacheffe profile, with an emphasis on delicate sweetness and brisk, complex flowers.

Name: Single-Estate Piko’s Peaberry
Review: ong>Inspiring story on the bag and crisp, subtle complexity in the cup.

Name: Single-Estate Medium
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a quiet, clean, subtly complex breakfast cup with an inspiring story.

Name: Monk-Shot Breakfast Blend
Review: ong>An attractive, complex and balanced alternative for Keurig owners. Maintains character well at a taller ten-ounce brew setting.

Name: Pure Arabica
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the moist foresty notes of Sumatra Arabica coffees may enjoy this understated variant on the style.

Name: House Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy pungent, rough beverages like retsina wines and mescals.

Name: Pure Robusta
Review: ong>Sensory adventurers interested in sampling a decent quality dried-in-the-fruit Robusta.

Name: Highland Grove
Review: ong>Aficionado adventurers curious about this very unusual blend of coffee species, although the impact of dry-processing (drying in the fruit) and a darkish roast may obscure any clear view of the sensory impact of species.

Name: Festival Blend
Review: ong>This is a coffee for aficionados curious about this very rare blend of coffee species, although the impact of dry-processing (drying in the fruit) and a darkish roast may obscure any clear view of the sensory impact of species.

Name: Ethiopia Worka Natural
Review: ong>Complex, pleasing variation on the chocolate-and-brandy dried-in-the-fruit Yirgacheffe profile and an excellent value.

Name: Ethiopian Duromina
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the honeyish, crisply sweet, meadowy character of a very pure washed coffee at a relatively light roast.
Coffee Origin: Gomma Woreda, Limu region, southwestern Ethiopia.

Name: 100% Ethiopian
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a discreetly roast-muted version of the floral- and fruit-toned Ethiopia profile at a very attractive price.

Name: 100% Ethiopian (K-Cup)
Review: ong>Keurig owners interested in an excellent value Ethiopia coffee that preserves some of the character of the origin in a darker roasted style.

Name: Forbidden Cave of Maya Guatemalan Blend
Review: ong>Those who prefer resonant depth to crisp brightness in a straight shot. Should hold its character well in taller milk drinks.
